job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Culture pushes you to do more than you would expect coming in. Overall, is filled with great people who want to produce and discover as much as they can.
cons: The culture that demand success and constant effort can seem overbearing at times. Medical campus can seem very impersonal. Parking is terrible and parking garages are not free for students during normal work hours. Many students opt for street parking but have been ticketed multiple times and/or towed at least once.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Employee discounts / Corporate Perks program
Health and life – Medical, dental, FSA, disability, life insurance, legal assistance and more.
Healthy@Hopkins – Rewards program, Wellnet services and Employee Health and Wellness Center.
Paid time off / vacation
Qualifying Status Changes
Retirement and pension
Training and education
Tuition assistance
Work, Life and Engagement programs
cons: Long hours and no room for negotiating pay, hiring manager and hr people decide what pay grade is.

pros:
Great networking opportunities if you're looking to move forward in your career.
Great people to work with. 
Meaningful work.
Flexible hours (though this depends on your PI).
cons: The pay isn't great. If money is a concern, as it is for most people, then you are probably better off finding similar coordinator positions in private companies.

pros: Johns Hopkins is a great place to work right out of college to get the best experience out there to prepare you for further education or a higher position!
cons: Since Johns Hopkins is an academic institute they do not offer very competitive salaries.  This is the only downside of working for Johns Hopkins.

review_title: While Hopkins is fantastic, Dept of BME needs help.
pros: There is always exciting research going on with numerous potential collaborations.  Most labs are willing to help each other with time, knowledge, or materials.  Terrific health care benefits.
cons: Very little and expensive parking.  The hospital is in a bad neighborhood.  Professors, while brilliant, are usually absent-minded and frequently travel.  The BME department offers very few good graduate classes (most are senior level) and little help with moving toward graduation.

review_title: Extremely difficult to make it in academia here
pros: Great HR benefits, the chance to take classes to improve your skills, researchers at the top of their game
cons: Extremely cut-throat faculty members, lack of mentor-ship, a lot of positions are based on soft money so absolutely no job security even if you are staff

review_title: It was a wonderful place. The staff there were absolutely nice and very helpful and resourceful.
pros: The pros are that once you are in the Johns hopkins family its easier for you to move around for professional growth.
cons: The cons were that if you are temporary even at your best efforts you could be let go of due to hiring status. I encourage you to keep trying!!!

review_title: Great science w/ lots of egos and dependent admin/operations
pros:
-Cutting edge and novel science 
-Evolved and leadership supported focus on applied/translational science
-great for faculty
cons:
-Poor environment for staff who want to give meaningful input. Lots of robots, few independent thinkers among staff.
-necessary change takes a long time or never happens
-lots of No people, very few solution-oriented.
-pay is ok for Baltimore, but could still be better. 
-tuition reimbursement amount hasn’t changed for over 20 years, but tuition has steadily increased.

review_title: Prestigious place to work, but not the best place for a software engineer.
pros: Hopkins is a very prestigious place to work. They offer great benefits including a compressive insurance and tuition reimbursement to Johns Hopkins University.
cons: Although it is a prestigious place to work, for someone with an advanced technical degree, your opportunities are limited. Tuition reimbursement to Johns Hopkins University only counts if you can get into the university.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Baltimore, MD
pros: Johns Hopkins University is a collegial and friendly atmosphere, with many supportive faculty members. Pay as a graduate student is quite liveable for the Baltimore area. The student healthcare is good.
cons: The payroll doesn’t always respond quickly when there are problems, and at least for my department there are problems once a year with me getting paychecks.

pros: Having "Johns Hopkins" on your CV looks good no matter what. Hopkins has a reputation for excellence.
cons:
Pay grade is low across the board.
Benefits used to be good but the institution has dramatically cut health benefits while increasing the cost of coverage.
You may see a maximum 2% increase which doesn't cover cost of living expenses increase.
Opportunity for growth is limited for a variety of disciplines and HR & management are not helpful with working with employees to shape and achieve career goals.

review_title: JHU is good place to have your Ph.D
job_title: Ph D Student in Baltimore, MD
pros:
People are very nice in university.  Research is a bit intense and you have work hard to contribute. 
I'm lucky to work with a smart and friendly professor here.
cons: I'm more concerned about the safety. Although I know the university has tried pretty hard to keep the campus and adjacent area safe. However,  you have to always be careful and keep alert.

review_title: A great place to work if you don't want to get fired...
pros: Stable employment, some management actually care
cons: No mobility, lots of bureaucracy, no accountability, impossible to get rid of cruft. The performance system doesn't reward excellence and instead protects mediocrity.

job_title: Marketing Graphic Designer in Washington, DC
pros: Stability, name has gravitas. They get by on their good name.
cons: Decentralized organization, slow moving, was difficult to accomplish much in-house as a creative due to lack of buy-in. No opportunity for growth within organization. Leadership was disengaged with administrative staff.

review_title: great university for healthcare and innovation
pros: You can access to the first hand healthcare data and people. And you will find a lot of opportunities if you are interested in healthcare innovation.
cons: The innovation support from the university is not as much strong as other universities like Stanford or MIT. The surrounding environment and the Baltimore area may not be the best place for startups.

pros: Gorgeous campus, great employees, strong focus on overall mission to help patients
cons: Low pay across the board (all positions, clinical and administrative). The company justifies paying its staff low wages by saying you can "put Hopkins on your resume" and by providing above average benefits. The result is a high turnover rate and low job satisfaction from employees. It also doesn't help that the patient population in East Baltimore is less than ideal.

pros: (JHSPH, Office of External Affairs, Web Team) Open, honest, supportive director, easy-going environment, lots of opportunities to grow through subscriptions to tutorial sites and conferences, opportunity to grow a single brand, high value on work/life balance, lots of paid time off, great(!!!) retirement benefits, decent healthcare benefits.
cons: Very non-competitive salary, limited exposure to emerging technologies, limited design scope.

pros:
Great benefits.
Options for flexible work hours.
Good experience
cons: Research positions are not well compensated. I sat on a focus group to determine why we were losing research assistants and other research support staff. The conclusion:  lots of opposition from HR to promoting individuals within departments; strong opposition to paying higher salaries,a s the Hopkins salaries were "competitive." They are not when compared to industry salaries.

pros: The lab are good place to start any experience in Medical research. Many different areas of medicine and public health are being studied here.
cons: Hopkins doesn't pay as well as working for a private entity. This is obvious. However, you do get to work with some of the leaders in their field and you don't get to do that very often.

review_title: Respecting of differences and working in the best interests of people.
pros:
-Feel like you are affecting real-world change.
-Are part of a very large community.
-Good benefits and resources.
-The emphasis on diversity and acceptance in all forms is the best I have ever seen.
cons:
-Often decentralized with lack of communication between silos.
-Can find one's self in a dead-end if not careful.
-Things can move very slowly in a career path, particularly with salaries.

review_title: A great place to gain top-notch experience.
job_title: Business Project Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Of course, reputation.   Followed by the learning experience.  It's a robust organization in a challenging, multifaceted industry.   It's got decent benefits and great work-life balance.
cons: The organization is so fragmented it damages leadership's potential.  The pay is not competitive.

review_title: It is a very academic university. Situations vary from department to department, but in general the stress level is high
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
cons:
The safety of the neighborhood is a concern, especially for medical campus;
Professors who focus more on lecturing is not appreciated enough.

review_title: Advanced Academic Programs Online, Not Worth a Flimsy Degree
pros: Few excellent faculty who gave great online instruction and can deliver an exceptional performance (20% in my department were legit) - Flexibility regarding time and mobility in online education – and that's about it
cons:
Very incompetent directors steal the show (aka 'riding the legacy train') and then abruptly leave JHU right in the middle of semesters - Faculty used to be open and more transparent to the student but now it feels very distant, even in their teaching practices, and this is already a remote program - Extremely flimsy MS degrees granted from a large named university (its definitely not a positive in industry and it can cause irreversible damage to your resume), the coursework is much lighter than it should be - No pressure applied by faculty but there is definitely dysfunction on JHU's end applied to an online graduate student - Some of the courses are downright subpar, even below community college level, and should be replaced - These same courses are taught by either very weak or very strong researchers who don't seem to like teaching but only enjoy taking the glory of adding JHU Faculty to their CV  

Most AAP programs have little entrance standards so your classmates are a very wide, unpredictable mixture from the super incompetent and clueless student to the exceptionally talented student, which hurts the talented folks because the mess is dragged into the program - The programs demonstrate a let anyone in the door attitude and it reflects in the student body, the poor performance and laziness of several students, it tampers with the seriousness of better quality, motivated students, and this large overlap will eventually tarnish AAP's reputation if left in place - Students range from the MDs at a private medical practice, to the gasoline attendant at your local block, to active Assistant & Associate Professors, to the international students living in other countries who find AAP programs too easy and leave, to highly experienced Project Managers in major US corporations, and to the guy who cuts the lawns of those same US corporations each week (it really doesn't matter folks, AAP will take them all) - To me, the admission standards at AAP seems like: 'if you have money to burn, come join us because we will easily ignite it for you, with very miniscule benefit to you in return' - horrible, damaging, and completely unacceptable to students/professionals at all levels

Incredibly high turnover in faculty members that are not announced (anymore) – this leads to a "cheap educational" feeling from students who are spending hard earned money on education that is driven by most faculty whom do not take AAP serious enough and then run off with a JHU Faculty Member line item on their resume - I noticed several students transferring from one AAP program to the next AAP program, just in search for a better education - Thanks to JHU AAP, the final transcript has almost half-dozen different names under 'Advisor' because the previous people left the university over a short period of time - Now the graduates are viewed as indecisive, unstable, and unpredictable in regards to working under approved faculty, which is entirely not the case but it sure looks like it to outside companies, trust me

Do not interact with the IT department here – very poor quality people and even higher turnover, they pretend to help you and then report back bloated responses - Managers are immature, unprofessional and dirty - Engineers will just point out obvious problems, bicker and complain but they won't actually solve them - You are better off going to a close friend who works in the IT industry for legitimate, honest technical assistance because AAP's IT is a disgrace to the system

The coursework is entirely variable – its almost as if the faculty never talk to each other when building up courses in the programs - There is no cohesion between courses and no pattern to follow, as you are left with taking random courses per term - Its a large drawback for this method of education so be smart, stay away, and do not waste your money in online education here

pros: There are excellent opportunities for research and great colleagues to work with. Overall an excellent benefits package.
cons: The accounting system is a nightmare. There is a tendency to create excessive complexity in the employee evaluation process while at the same time looking for excessively simple evaluation metrics that don't map well to the often complex and somewhat ambiguous nature of much of academic work.

job_title: Undergraduate Student Researcher in Baltimore, MD
pros: There are so many interesting labs to work at. It is definitely worth taking on a research position at some time during your undergraduate career.
cons: Make sure you are aware of the hours you will need to work and whether or not they need to be in chunks. Budget time for studying as well as classes, including near exam time, because nothing is worse than being in lab and worrying about a test you didn't study for.

review_title: Great organization, but a little too decentralized
pros: Company clearly has brand equity, power in the community, great support for staff who wants to take training and development  (classes are free!!
cons: Difficult to work in such a decentralized structure and navigating politics of each entity. Depending on your staff and personality type, you can succeed or struggle with this piece.

pros: Johns Hopkins University is a very attractive employer in many areas.  It's an intellectually challenging environment, there are plenty of opportunities for professional networking and training, benefits are very good and work-life balance is respected.
cons: Working at Johns Hopkins University contains its downside.  Some faculty and senior staff are protected due to reputation, despite their abusive, mean attitude and deportment towards staff.  Some members of executive leadership have disregard for department-level management.

job_title: Communications Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: I had a very flexible schedule and could work hours when it was easy for me. As a student it worked out well as I could work when I had the time.
cons: One of the major cons of working as a graduate research assistant was that my work was largely busy work. I was support staff.

pros:
- Academic and intellectual achievement of faculty and staff
- Ability to work and attend graduate school
- Career advancement opportunities
- Ability to schedule classes around work hours to actually finish your degree, including intersession classes, evening classes, and online courses
- Good medical benefits, including wonderful eye care at Hopkins
cons:
- The tuition reimbursement for full time workers is much too low compared to the salaries and price per course
- Not the best dental plans

pros:
- Being among scholars and cutting edge researchers.
- Benefits.
- Room for growth/advancement/change.
- Training and educational opportunities.
- Employee support.
cons: Like any place, there are always office politics and strong personalities but nothing I have seen has been all that bad.  There are many avenues through HR if a situation were that bad.  I have heard, though not yet experienced, that the President can be a bit hard on people he's directly in contact with.

review_title: Friendly, encouraging workplace that offers both a challenging work environment and quality reputation.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: The school (and research) lives up to its reputation. Everyone is very concerned with integrity and quality research. Very open to mentoring and helping build professional skills.
cons: The work load is incredibly demanding and fast paced. Sometimes people expect you to know something without really explaining it. Very competitive student base.

pros: Exceptional IT infrastructure to support Intelligent people, applying advanced science, engineering, and technology to challenges that demand systems thinking.
cons: Myopic management, stovepipe organizational structures, outdated, nepotistic staffing policies, and minimal effective leadership training limit staff development and management capability, despite genuine change efforts and technical capability.

pros: Undergraduate research is easy to come by and the professors are very inclined to allow undergraduate students to work with them on a project.
cons: salary is below average.  No free parking.  As anybody in research knows - there isn't much room for growth unless someone leaves of you move to another study.

pros: I feel that my opinions are valued and that I am given a lot of freedom and flexibility to complete my work.
cons: Good quality mentorship is lacking. Hypothesis-based research is  not endorsed. Management does not address conflict within the workplace.  Pay insufficient to compensate for the required work.

pros: The right professors and classes are great to TA for, the students are usually pretty friendly and usually appreciate your work.
cons: Time consuming if doing it while pursuing a degree, some profs are a pain. Some students are belligerent and don't like it when you grade them fairly, although this is a fairly uncommon occurrence. Some profs leave you as the sole determiner for grades, which leads to uncomfortable situations.

pros: Everyone in the Office of Summer and Intersession programs is so warm and friendly. It's the best job I've had on campus. I enjoy going to work and feel like part of the team--it doesn't feel like work. My supervisor is really kind and really tries to give me tasks that will help develop the skills I need for my future career plans.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

review_title: Great place where you can actually contribute to society
pros: Always surrounded with smart people, experts in their fields, everybody is heard, lots of opportunities to watch great people give talks, very easy access to resources, both faculty and management are always willing to support continuous learning.
cons: The only and the biggest con would be location, should definitely look up Baltimore before considering a position, especially if you have certain standards when it comes to social city life.

job_title: Senior Community Outreach Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great work for the community and serving the public health department. See the impact of your work towards the end of the research project...
cons: Health care politics played a role in stripping the amount of outreach to certain clinics. Unpredictable project; rules and procedures were constantly changing.

review_title: Officer Manager, EMR Specialist, Mobile Application Creator, Reseach Assistant, Medical Assistant
job_title: Junior Physician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Friendly environment, happy employees, good benefits, exponential learning and earning opportunities and the option to travel
cons: Limited moving abilities. At present, would like to diversify my knowledge base in different areas of research and science.

pros: Great benefits, great teammates, flexible work schedule, intelligent people, not overly long hours, other words to reach the twenty word minimum
cons: some of the downsides to working at johns hopkins bloomberg school of public health are the low salaries and lack of career growth. We actually don't know if that is true.

pros:
Good insurance policies with sliding scales depending on base salary
Nice campus
Individually, offices are great to work with
cons: Senior Management is very top heavy, Vice- President of this, Sr. Vice President of that. very little empathy for staff.

job_title: Health Assistant in La Mesa, CA
pros: They pay for housing, you get to explore a new city or place, and all the money you make is net profit since they pay for food, etc.  The kids are great too.
cons: As a health assistant, doing first aid/keeping the kids healthy was great, but if the management is inexperienced or if the nurse is new you may be in for a hard time.

pros:
-great benefits; just expanded to include paid leave for new mothers and fathers. 
-lots of training opportunities 
-interesting work but dependent on department you work for.
cons:
-no path for promotion 
-overworked without proper compensation 
-high turnover 
-crowded and sometimes difficult to find space to work.

review_title: A great experience.  Very bright Professors.  Lots of opportunities for research inside and outside the department.
pros: Some of the brightest minds around.  Lots of interdisciplinary potential.  If you are a health researcher, the hospital is one of the best in the world.
cons: Limited resources as compared to some of the other prestigious schools.  It has a smaller endowment, which means there are fewer in-house funding opportunities and the departments tend to be smaller.

review_title: A community that supports it's employees, student, and faculty.
pros: JHU truly cares about their employees and their community. Benefits are amazing (health, dental, benefits savings plan, education reimbursement for the employee and their family, and more). They support their employees and help them succeed and grow. JHU's values to the surrounding community and culture are admirable.
cons: The pay for support staff, while competitive, does leave a bit to be desired. HOWEVER, they make up for it in benefits.

review_title: Great Resume Builder, Salaries Under Market Value
pros: Fantastic place to learn and grow for early career professionals. The faculty/students are amazing to work with.
cons: Very political and polarized work environment. Hard to advance from within, they always look to hire externally for management/leadership roles. Also, salaries are under market value and raises are minimal. Negotiate as high as you can get at the offer point because it won't go up much from there, even if you are a high performer.

pros: Nice campus, interesting research, reasonable compensation
cons: The mindset and the work ethic is extremely stale. The beaurocracy is astounding, even compare to other higher ed institutions. Nothing works the way it should, on-boarding is abysmal, 10 departments that do the same thing but don't talk to one another, very very VERY decentralized (and this is coming from someone who worked at Penn and Temple University)

review_title: Generally good work environment but difficult time for leadership
pros: Access to professional development is excellent. Generally a smart, inclusive, modern workplace.
cons: Many departments have grown quickly at Hopkins, and the leadership is not quite as thoughtful as they could or should be about managing that. Some VPs are strongly disliked. At lower levels as well, many staff and faculty have spent their whole careers at JHU, making organizational progress extremely difficult.

pros: Good environment, flexible, work-life balance, exposure to cutting-edge science and medicine, benefits are decent
cons: Very low salary compared to similar positions at other organizations, does not pay competitively for Baltimore City, HR makes it very difficult to advance, tuition remission is not great, benefits are not worth the low pay

job_title: Philosophy Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: incredible students, room and board
cons: location, low responsibility, minimum wage

pros:
One of the best research universities, just to name a few:
Excellent academic environment
Open opportunities for every student
Access to cutting edge technology
Proficient in both fundamental and translational research
cons:
Health insurance for homewood students is not satisfactory
Working in another campus (other than the home campus) could be a pain
Very little social life for grad students
Career center mostly focuses on undergrads

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Tuition benefit for dependents and self; wide variety of positions and locations; interesting co-workers and leaders.
cons: Changes to the tax plan will cause a lot of problems -- but even before that, lower pay than at other universities; position depends on personality of your boss; wide variety in job descriptions/pay from office to office, i.e., SOM and Press jobs tend to pay less.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nice Summer Job. Felt like a paid vacation. The kids are awesome to work with because they're really eager to learn and very friendly and not rambunctious. That varies from class to class but my group was great. They gave us a night out to celebrate on the beach and payed for dinner at a Sushi buffet. Got to meet some really awesome people.
cons: None I can think of at the moment.

review_title: APL is a good place to work, but could be improved
pros: Flexabililty, job security, Ok salary.  State of the art work mostly for the defense community, especially the navy.
cons: little reward for excellent performance.  There is no bonuses, only very small merit rewards given out in secret.

review_title: It was a great University to work for
pros: Great and helpful staff. Easy process. Veteran TAs are very helpful with learning ropes and Professors are loyal to those that work under them. Take it seriously and put the time in and virtually guaranteed another position in following semesters.
cons: There were no cons working here other than make sure you know what you are getting into for the amount of hours you are getting paid for.

job_title: Writing Center Consultant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great co-workers in the writing center, you learn as much as you teach the students.  Shifts are flexible and short, so you can work them into your schedule.
cons: Pay could be higher, especially when compared to other, less intensive student jobs, but overall not bad.

review_title: Prestigious but depends on your department
job_title: Development and Alumni Relations in Baltimore, MD
pros: JHU is one of the most prestigious universities and healthcare systems in the world. It is an honor to represent the university and to engage donors by sharing all of the incredible achievements taking place there.
cons: Hopkins is the largest private employer in Maryland. Your work experience depends on the specific department you're in and who your supervisor is. The university provides excellent benefits overall, but your day-to-day employee experience can vary.

pros: SECURITY - Johns Hopkins University is looking to expand and finds itself in the two areas of the economy that is experiencing growth Medical and Education.
cons: The location is sometimes and issue for me because of commuting, as well as the limitations for growth in a big organization.

pros: Leading research institute, access to experts and opportunities to grow as a researcher and work alongside some of the brightest minds in the field
cons: University basically hires overqualified people for each of the advertised positions - so basically you are in a highly competitive environment, but are underpaid and there are minimal employee training opportunities.  HR is unimaginably slow and inept.

pros:
- my P I has a laissez-faire attitude but with high expectations and is very helpful
- great flexibility of working anywhere and wherever is convenient
cons: - coworkers can be competitive and unhelpful, or have very busy schedules such that it is hard to stay on schedule

pros: Good benefits, free schooling, intelligent colleagues
cons: Administrators and staff not paid very good.  Prejudice  abounds in administration, old boy network, treat faculty researchers better then administration and staff

pros: Best place to work as a researcher, with great opportunities, good work culture, friendly co-workers, good balance between work and studies, and good mentorship for the future.
cons: Pay is very low as its an academic institute, with all research positions depends on the grants. Take a long time from job posting, to interview to employment.

review_title: Excellent benefits, exceptional departmental hr, great atmosphere, friendly coworkers
pros: Resume building potential, top-notch reasonably priced benefits, being part of a large family of researchers, state-of-the-art technologies and resources, transportation ease (shuttle network pretty helpful), access to credit union which offers excellent banking and loan options.
cons: There isn't anything bad I can think of about my experience working here.

pros:
It was a part time job that also offered remote working opportunity.
I went to the office for exactly one week after which I worked from home.
great flexibility to create own work hours
cons: No one to supervise  your work or comment on it. you are left on you own to do things.

pros:
* Good visibility
* Brand name university
cons:
* Medical school is located in a bad area, high crime, many shootings. 
* High security
* Better training for bosses needed on people skills
* High stress environment, bosses can be very stressed

pros:
-Great research experience for students taking a break after undergrad to decide on PhD topic or specialization.
-A lot of exposure to faculty, PhD students and other post docs and they can even give some useful tips on how to apply and other funding opportunities.
cons: -Parking can be expensive if you own a car (if not they have good shuttle service)

pros: Great medical and dental benefits, frequent checks in equity pay and performance reviews, tuition remission.
cons: HR in department is difficult to work with - asking for a raise/change in job title when the PI requests it is a long painstaking process. (Note that this is only in one particular department - I've worked in a different school/department under the Hopkins umbrella and that wasnt the case).

pros: Big Company therefore there is a very good scope of advancement after working here. Resume looks very good with such a big brand name to it.
cons: In comparison to industry standards, the salary is very very low and basic. A professional can be stuck in his or her career.

review_title: people are nice. a lot of intelligent people
pros: The supervisor is very nice, and I am happy to work for him during PhD if it is possible. The supervisor is very nice, and I am happy to work for him during PhD if it is possible.
cons: the salary won't be very high. The supervisor is very nice, and I am happy to work for him during PhD if it is possible.

pros: remote access is a wonderful when you do not need some one looking over your shoulder.  Independent and  work any time.
cons: It is a little hard during the initial training but when you get use to the system, there is no problem.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Advisor is great! Environment is great! I enjoyed working here quite a lot.  And I learned a lot from here.
cons: The pay is not very good here but the compensation and benefits are top notch. Also there are numerous school affiliated to Hopkins, they are not very connected.

review_title: A great deal of work not in job description
job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Pretty good benefits and a lot of open positions across university. Like freedom to get actual work done. Many opportunities for training and educational opportunities
cons: Small minded school no desire or direction to use technology. Many could telecommute but management is so against. Employees feel under threat of always losing their jobs.

pros: There are tons of great opportunities for grad students in engineering/science at JHU.  Stipends are good, but vary with department.
cons: Payements for student accounts get messed up a lot since they are usually dependent on both the department and research supervisor releasing the money from their respective accounts.

pros: Johns Hopkins is very prestigious and the name alone opens many doors.  There are a lot of brilliant people there and many opportunities to collaborate with colleagues.
cons: Because everyone is so smart, it's easy to feel inadequate at times.  I really don't like Baltimore and the East Baltimore campus is in a horrible neighborhood.

pros: Great access to resources, great environment for collaboration, easy  access to world class technical expertise in diverse aread, and great HR benefits
cons: The location is not the best, and there are some existing security issues which hinder mobility

review_title: Johns Hopkins University remains a world leader in both teaching and research. Eminent professors mentor top students
pros: Those same faculty members, and their research colleagues at the university's Applied Physics Laboratory, have each year since 1979 won Johns Hopkins more federal research and development funding than any other university.
cons: Salary is low. could be stressful at time, though the great students and post docs are thinking about leaving

job_title: Lead Technician/Classroom Audio Production Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: I am glad to be working in a job that is simmilar to what I love.
cons: My task are very elementry and not quite what I really like to do.  i would much rather be working as an Audio Engineer at a live event or a studio.

review_title: Great place to grow, very flexible
pros: Very flexible in terms of hours, oversight appropriate, not overbearing
cons: Little direction, can be too loose in terms of structure

job_title: Academic Program Administrator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Nice perks but that is not enough to stay employed here. It's located close to the subway system.
cons: I worked at the school of nursing and there is no diversity but they constantly talk about how to become more diverse. Just hire more minorities!!!! They quick to eliminate your position and expect you to stay! And they have no respect for the work you do. You are nothing more than a worker bee.

job_title: Associate Director of Financial Aid in Baltimore, MD
pros: I love many of the people I work with at my level. It all depends on the office and the division.
cons: Leadership can live in a bubble and be driven by revenue rather than responsibility. Lots of bad apples spoil it and the good ones leave. High turnover.

review_title: Flex hours makes this place an excellent work environment
job_title: Senior Professional Staff II in Laurel, MD
pros:
(a) Flexible work hours
(b) If you are lucky you may be working on a very technically challenging project which may lead to several publications
(c) Wealth of subject matter experts makes this  place a top notch research institute.
cons: It is my impression that salaries are low with respect to other industrial R&D institutes.

pros: A great undergraduate institution with plenty of academic and research opportunities. Adequate student life including dining, recreation, and entertainment.
cons: Do not expect a easy academic ride. You might not be warmly welcome by all the people you meet here. Safety is an issue if you are out late.

job_title: Ph D Student in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good access to computational resources
cons: Same cons with all Ph.Ds. The faculty has far too much leverage in the student/faculty relationship.

review_title: flexible, comfortable work environment for scientific staff
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Baltimore, MD

review_title: A good place to do science

review_title: Great place to continue your career education and learn a lot
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Baltimore, MD
pros: Time off is great, continuing education great, college benefits for kids is great

pros:
If you have kids in college, the tuition benefit is outstanding.
Vacation is good.
Healthcare is good.
Tuition remission is good, and they are usually flexible to allow you to take classes.
cons:
The salaries are low in exchange for the "prestige" of working at Hopkins. 
Firing people is nearly impossible so some of your colleagues won't do any work but still get the same benefits as you.

pros:
-All of the graduate students were fantastic people, always willing to assist with any projects I undertook

-Great reputation that comes with the name
cons:
-Projects were occasionally lacking in depth and complexity and came down to plug and chug or grunt work

pros: Great people; good salary (for a part-time job); good support from staff
cons: Homewood campus does NOT support CTY's summer camp - they do not assign us the rooms and space that we need, and campus security and the Registrar's office begrudges us every small request.

pros: Incredible opportunities for collaboration within the School or with the medical campus, facilities and resources are top-notch. Beautiful “vertical campus”, with a gym, multiple food options, a coffee shop, and plenty of spaces for working.
cons: As a postdoctoral fellow, I have a difficult time connecting with my peers. The School has not done a good job at connecting us or fostering inter-professional connections among us.

review_title: Provides education, research (clinical/non-clinical), and patient services through JHH System.
pros: Has good health benefits if managed through the Johns Hopkins Hospital. Never board in a fast pace with highly motivated faculty who work in a variety of academic disciplines.
cons: It is located in Baltimore City, that has a high crime rate and can be difficult to work and live in. Always have to have a since of where your are.

review_title: an excellent place to train for public health - international or domestic
pros: great reputation. excellent opportunities to work with world class faculty, especially in international health. many faculty are quite busy so one must work hard to seek them out opportunities though.
cons: very research driven. as a student was disappointed by some basic public health classes there.

pros: Pay is a bit low, benefits are great, and the people are nice. They treat the employees well, and management is competent.
cons: The bureaucracy makes things hard to get done, there is little drive towards excellence, the IT structure is duct taped together.

pros: A well run university, which respects it's faculty, staff and students.  Individual contributions are welcomed and appreciated.  The University recognizes that "the whole is only as good as the sum of it's parts".
cons: It is a necessarily bureaucratic organization, so there is a certain way that things need to be done. There are forms and procedures for everything.

pros: Great academic institution overall with great name, a lot of amazing people around, great work culture and networking opportunities.
cons: Dependence on the grant support - became less reliable recently, the employment is never secure. Pay is not the greatest. Really bad neighborhood - with all the assaults and robbing taking place on streets just a few steps away from the campus, you can never feel safe.

pros: Postdoc experience is very dependent on the lab and advisor, so choose wisely. Pay is comparable or higher compared to other engineering-based postdocs. Also depends on the lab.
cons: Postdoc hours could be very long and pay is not very reasonable considering industry options in engineering. Insurance is decent unless you have a family to cover in which case it can be as high as 11K.

review_title: Development and Alumni Relations is a meat grinder and cult-like
pros: The mission you're raising money for can be great, depending on the school or program. Choose carefully.
cons:
Don't do it, unless you like being treated like a cog. The whole "Hopkins Way" ethos is arrogant and smells like fecal
matter ,and morale vampires lurk everywhere. If misery and toxic workplaces are your thing, you might love it. Trust no one.  But hey, you'll learn a lot!

pros: just graduated from this unviersity, carey business school. only few teachers are good enough to be mentioned. others are just part time workers.
cons: not all the professors are professional enough to worth the money we pay for each class. but the rank is high.

review_title: You get out what you put in.
pros: There are many opportunities here to grow but you must seek them out,,, nothing and I mean nothing is handed to you here,,,,to thrive here you must seek and strive to learn all the time.
cons: Too many lifers here that think the Hopkins way is the only way.

pros: Pay. Technology. This is a reasonably good place to work. A great number of very talented subject matter experts. Good job security.
cons: Matrix management. Poor leadership. Systems engineering is supposed to be the strong point but it is often very weak.

review_title: Great place to do high end research but salaries are not the best.
pros: Great research environment with amazing collaborations. Faculty are generally willing to share their data and start new projects in collaboration. Benefits are better than average, especially the tuition assistance for dependents.
cons: Salaries tend to be lower than the national average. Potential for growth might be difficult, especially in a clinical department.

pros: Great program for the kids; I TA'd the engineering class for the younger kids. It was a lot of fun; definitely easier for the TAs than the RAs.
cons: Experience really depends on how well you get along with your teacher. The first year, I got stuck with a woman who delighted in terrorizing our kids; second year at a different location was so so much better.

pros: Intellectually stimulating workplace. The environment fosters professional and intellectual growth as the University allows access to high profile academics and thinkers who ready to mentor others.
cons: JHU can be a bit bureaucratic. So most projects require a long process they can be approved even when they are quite minor.

pros: The school is known for their top of the field scientists. This creates an environment where you will have the best colleagues who hold one another to the highest standards. There is a true commitment to excellence that defines the culture.
cons: Everyone here works really hard. You aren't required to work outside the office, but it is expected and necessary to succeed.

pros: Some good benefits, very nice campus, pay is somewhat decent
cons:
There is very little organization in top management. Often times the left hand has no idea what the right hand is doing. This became a troubling sign early on, as mid level managers who did not have the skills to work well with other employees were given tasks to train new employees. 
There is a very high turnover rate that not a lot of people are willing to discuss.
The 120 day probationary period can be a bit excessive and not employee friendly. This is considering the fact that Hopkins benefits are not as competitive with other industries that have great vacation and PTO. 
Baltimore is a rough place to work and not welcoming to people who make life changes to be in the area. Between the crime that is constantly near campus, lack of emotional support, and little understanding from those who are employed from the outside, Hopkins is notorious for being in a declining city that has multiple problems. Employees get at least one email a day of an armed robbery near campus, students who get mugged on a walk back to their dorm, and bomb threats.
It is not uncommon to walk outside and find all the windows of the cars next to you busted and/or dented up. If you want parking that won’t be in dangerous areas of the city, it will cost around $110 a month.
Tuition benefits are standard for employees. I personally have heard of universities that do more in the way of help for their staff though. My honest opinion, if you want to work in education and are pursuing a masters at the same time, Hopkins makes it extremely tough to go to school and work. I have interviewed multiple employees in their mid 20’s who have tried to do both work and school through Hopkins and it led to them having to make a choice between the two. Lack of support between schooling and work is quite concerning for an institution that preached higher education. 

Overall: My suggestion is that if your younger, do not look at Johns Hopkins. Your much better being in a city like Washington DC, Philadelphia, Boston, Seattle, Austin where the pay is competitive and the benefits are very competitive. Baltimore is a rough city that has very little to offer. It just so happens that Hopkins is a super power in a city that really does not have much more to offer. 
The high turnover rates and lack of diversity in staff comes at no surprise. 90% of the employees you will be working with are born and raised in the Baltimore region. Though the school preaches diversity in its student body, it could do more to follow with its back end staff. What I find interesting is the amount of Professors who are unwilling to live in the Baltimore area. Many times they are commenting from either DC or Philadelphia areas, where the job market and research can provide more opportunities for them.

pros: Lots of great minds here. Great supporting system for graduate student. Tons of collaborations between different labs.Graduate students receive tuition remission from school of medicine, Casey business school and school of public health. So it is convenient to explore different subjects.
cons: Accounting system is not good. Sometimes things can go really slow in a big institute like Hopkins. Medical campus is not that safe.

review_title: It is really a good school for scientist and students. The salary is OK, just house expense is too high in Baltimore.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: It is really a good school for scientist and students. The salary is OK, just house expense is too high in Baltimore.

pros: Great work/life balance, a lot of opportunities to grow, awesome benefits including tuition remission and assistance

review_title: It's been a good experience I want a more challenging job.
